docs.lead_paragraph: AND now, for my next act,'' Ned Gelfars said, ''I will attempt to juggle these pins.'' Then he asked the crowd of screaming children at Harbor Island Park here: ''Or should I do it while riding this unicycle? Who thinks I should ride it? Come here, what's your name?''

docs.lead_paragraph: I am a police officer, and I sometimes handle phone inquiries from family members about persons just arrested. When a wife asks about charges, and her husband has been arrested for soliciting a prostitute, I can withhold the information in the hope that he has learned his lesson, sparing her pain and humiliation, and perhaps preserving a marriage. But is a husband who violates the law and his vows entitled to my protection? And worse, withholding the truth could put the wife at risk of contracting a sexually transmitted disease. Should I tell or not? -- Anonymous, N. Y. You should tell. Your consideration for your callers is admirable, but your job is to provide public information, not pre-emptive marriage counseling. You ought not pick and choose among crimes, covering up some and revealing others. I may believe that Pizarro learned his lesson and genuinely regrets murdering Atahualpa and conquering the Incas, but if the ghost of Mrs. Pizarro calls, I'm obliged to tell her what he's doing time for.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: The Ethicist; Husbands and Lies

docs.abstract: The Ethicist column by Randy Cohen advises police officer on answering questions from relatives of people who have been arrested; owner of weekend home whose neighbor is growing marijuana; estate executor on moral obligation to pay bills owed by his late brother

docs.lead_paragraph: PERHAPS you think that what displeases your employer most are quarterly earnings reports, or workers who steal Post-it notes. But high on the list of annoyances is managing your health insurance. Choosing health care plans, negotiating rates and fighting claims add up to an expensive and irritating burden for most companies. Who wants to spend half the day on the phone with employees who are steaming over an unpaid claim, and the other half hearing from insurers about how doctors miscoded bills?

headline.main: Managing Benefits: Let Workers Do It

docs.abstract: Article explains 'defined contribution' approach to corporate health insurance benefits, in which employers simply give workers a fixed amount of money to purchase their own health insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Mexico's New President Promises to Share Power Vicente Fox Quesada, 58, the former business executive who led a national movement for democracy, became the first opposition politician in 71 years to be inaugurated president. He promised that he would share the power that the Institutional Revolutionary Party long monopolized. A1 House Arrest for Pinochet A Chilean judge charged Gen. Augusto Pinochet in the kidnappings of political opponents after he overthrew the Socialist government of Dr. Salvador Allende in 1973. The 85-year-old ailing general was ordered placed under house arrest. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The idea that the United States is increasingly a nation of entrepreneurs and self-starters has become accepted wisdom. ''Welcome to the free-agent nation,'' declares Tom Peters, one of the world's best-known management gurus.

headline.main: Entrepreneurs' 'Golden Age' Is Fading in Economic Boom

docs.abstract: Self-employment has declined in number and as share of work force, despite strong economy; large companies, desperate for additional workers, are luring employees, in part by offering some of benefits of self-employment; at same time, difficulties of entrepreneurship have become less tolerable; period between 1994 and 1999, hailed as golden age for entrepreneurs, is first five-year span since 1960's in which number of self-employed fell; by contrast, for most of last three decades, self-employment grew slightly faster than overall labor force; economists say widely believed hyperbole surrounding Internet and new economy has exaggerated ease with which people can start their own businesses; say running small business or acting as independent consultant has become harder than it once was; photo; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The idea that the United States is increasingly a nation of entrepreneurs and self-starters has become accepted wisdom.    ''Welcome to the free-agent nation,'' declares Tom Peters, one of the world's best-known management gurus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lou (the Toe) Groza, one of football's greatest place-kickers and a superb offensive tackle for the Cleveland Browns teams that dominated two leagues during the emergence of the modern professional game, died Wednesday night at a hospital in Middleburgh Heights, Ohio. He was 76. Groza, who had been in poor health, collapsed after attending a dinner with his wife, Jackie, at a country club. He apparently had a heart attack, The Associated Press reported.

headline.main: Lou Groza, 76, Star Kicker For Cleveland Browns, Dies

docs.lead_paragraph: Quaker Oats Seen Close To Accepting PepsiCo Deal Almost a month after rejecting PepsiCo's takeover offer as too low, Quaker Oats is close to reaching the same deal to be acquired by Pepsi for $14.3 billion, executives close to the talks said. The resumption of the talks comes after a decision by Coca-Cola's board last week to abandon its own $16 billion deal to buy Quaker Oats and its prize growth brand, Gatorade. Danone of France also expressed interest in a deal but declined to bid. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-20 Fear of Mad Cow Disease Sweeps Through Europe A panic that began in France several weeks ago has spread throughout Europe. Many countries are setting up new testing programs and banning one another's beef, trying to reassure consumers that the meat they are buying is free of contamination. But the efforts are having little success in calming consumer fears. A1 Boost for Labor in Britain A poll published in The Times of London found the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair regaining a large lead among voters, in anticipation of national elections expected in the spring. The opposition Conservatives have lost ground during a feud over leadership succession and a debate over authoritarian and libertarian brands of conservatism. A7

docs.lead_paragraph: Two powerful insurance groups said today that they were trying to negotiate a merger, forming a huge lobby that would speak with one voice on legislation to define patients' rights. The merger would join the Health Insurance Association of America, which began as a lobby for traditional insurance companies, with the American Association of Health Plans, which represents health maintenance organizations and managed care companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: AIR bags improve people's chances of surviving crashes, on average, but it is now sadly clear that the bags are deadly to some children and small adults. Two new studies help to show who benefits and who does not. A paper published in October in the American Journal of Public Health selected 13,000 crashes in 1993-96 from a federal database, and found 5,000 cases with enough data about the driver, the injuries and the car to be analyzed. The driver's air bag deployed in about a quarter of the crashes.

headline.main: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; When Air Bags Help, and Harm

docs.abstract: Autos on Friday column on studies assessing safety and effectiveness of air bags; overall finding of recent report is that at about 20 miles per hour the air bag's protective effect becomes large enough to offset injurious effect; study author Dr Maria Segui-Gomez explains; also noted is Web site, Progessive.com, that shows videos of highway safety crash tests (M)
